subject: WIP: Enable HTTP redirects
commitMessage:
WIP: Enable HTTP redirects

This commit attempts to add the concept of an SSL detector from beast,
and add the capability into bmcweb.  This allows directing multiple
socket files to the bmcweb instance, and bmcweb will automatically sort
out whether or not they're SSL, and give the correct response.  This
allows users to plug in erroneous urls like "https://mybmc:80" and they
will forward and work correctly.  This also means that https redirection
is as easy as opening a second socket file to bmcweb on port 80.

Some key design points:
The HTTP side of bmcweb implements the exact same http headers as the
HTTPS side, with the exception of HSTS, which is explicitly disallowed.
This is for consistency and security.
The HTTP redirector ONLY redirects the GET and HEAD verbs.  This is
because other routes are very likely to be sending credentials or data
in the clear, and we want to make it clear that that's not acceptable.
Today it returns 404 for other requests.

The above allows bmcweb builds to "select" the appropriate security
posture (http, https, or both) for a given channel using the
FileDescriptorName field within a socket file.  Items ending in:
both: Will support both HTTPS and HTTP redirect to HTTPS
https: Will support HTTPS only
http: will support HTTP only

Given the flexibility in bind statements, this allows administrators to
support essentially any security posture they like.  The openbmc
defaults are:
HTTPS + Redirect on both ports 443 and port 80 if http-redirect is
enabled

And HTTPS only if http-redirect is disabled.

Tested:
Previous commits ran the below tests.
Ran the server with http-redirect enabled.  Tried:

curl -vvvv --insecure --user root:0penBmc http://192.168.7.2/redfish/v1/Managers/bmc
*   Trying 192.168.7.2:80...
* Connected to 192.168.7.2 (192.168.7.2) port 80 (#0)
* Server auth using Basic with user 'root'
> GET /redfish/v1/Managers/bmc HTTP/1.1
> Host: 192.168.7.2
> Authorization: Basic cm9vdDowcGVuQm1j
> User-Agent: curl/7.72.0
> Accept: */*
>
* Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse
< HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
< Location: https://192.168.7.2
< X-Frame-Options: DENY
< Pragma: no-cache
< Cache-Control: no-Store,no-Cache
< X-XSS-Protection: 1; mode=block
< X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
< Content-Security-Policy: default-src 'none'; img-src 'self' data:; font-src 'self'; style-src 'self'; script-src 'self'; connect-src 'self' wss:
< Date: Fri, 08 Jan 2021 01:43:49 GMT
< Connection: close
< Content-Length: 0
<
* Closing connection 0

Observe above:
webserver returned 301 redirect.
webserver returned the appropriate security headers
webserver immediately closed the connection.

The same test above over https:// returns the values as expected

Loaded the webui to test static file hosting.  Webui logs in and works
as expected.

Used the scripts/websocket_test.py to verify that websockets work.
Sensors report as expected.

Change-Id: Ib5733bbe5473fed6e0e27c56cdead0bffedf2993
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <ed@tanous.net>

Patch Set 35:

Milton wrote https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-misc/commit/4ee8f2c55b20dbf1987d056fe436168ee574b654#diff-8cb8269ed622fa136a53747dfdcf19cc
Would like him to sign off on this is a better direction

Patch Set 35:

> Patch Set 35:
> 
> Milton wrote https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-misc/commit/4ee8f2c55b20dbf1987d056fe436168ee574b654#diff-8cb8269ed622fa136a53747dfdcf19cc
> Would like him to sign off on this is a better direction

I'd love his input.

My problem with the awk approach is that we're relying on an HTTP parser OpenBMC we wrote ourselves, which is a generally accepted anti-pattern, and difficult to get right.  That's not to say I question Miltons skills, but the tests there make me think that it hasn't had as rigorous of a testing as beast has.  Same goes for the URL parser.
Also, in that example, I see no mention of a timer, or body size limit, making it a great attack vector if someone is hoping to DOS attack the BMC.  We seem to be compiling regular expressions for each request?  That seems like a problem for the BMC startup times.
Most importantly, the AWK approach is 592 lines of security-impacting code the project now has to maintain.  This patchset is a net negative line count, due to some of the continued housekeeping of http_connection, and simplifying a lot of assumptions.

In this implementation, we have essentially the same security model as bmcweb-secure, and rely on a parser that's been fuzzed and tested heavily, as well as rely on the same code we already have to get right in the secure case.

With all of the above said, I'm happy to be told I've missed something.

Patch Set 35:

> My problem with the awk approach is that we're relying on an HTTP parser OpenBMC we wrote ourselves, which is a generally accepted anti-pattern, and difficult to get right.

I agree with you but ironically IMO the whole of bmcweb falls into this category (nginx).  And the new telemetry application (collectd).  And phosphor-hwmon.  And dbus-sensors.  (lm-sensors).  In all those cases the rationale I've heard for not using those pre-existing codebases was simply because it is/was easier to roll our own </half-baked-unfiltered-thoughts>

(1 comment)

> Patch Set 35:
> 
> > My problem with the awk approach is that we're relying on an HTTP parser OpenBMC we wrote ourselves, which is a generally accepted anti-pattern, and difficult to get right.
> 
> I agree with you but ironically IMO the whole of bmcweb falls into this category (nginx).  And the new telemetry application (collectd).  And phosphor-hwmon.  And dbus-sensors.  (lm-sensors).  In all those cases the rationale I've heard for not using those pre-existing codebases was simply because it is/was easier to roll our own </half-baked-unfiltered-thoughts>

In every other case you listed, it's an internal daemon talking to internal APIs, where mistakes aren't likely to become major security issues.  My point above was specifically about HTTP parsers when interacting directly to unauthenticated, possibly attacking clients.  It should be noted, I wish we could've used nginx, but the last time I prototyped it (a precursor to bmcweb), it was damn near impossible to write secure nginx plugins that did what OpenBMC needed.  I do get your point, we write a lot of openbmc-specific stuff, but my response wasn't intended to be a comment about the projects direction as a whole, simply that specific case, of a "security conscious" network API boundary, needed a lot of careful inspection.  We should strive to rely on as little openbmc code as we can in those situations.

This patchset is mostly using library functions, and wrapping them in the logic that OpenBMC needed to be compatible, hence why the patchset turned out to be 12 lines less than the old code.  I think that's a win for using things our libraries already provide instead of writing it ourselves.

One more note: I wish the telemetry service was a thin dbus wrapper around collectd with an rrd backend.  That would be ideal in my mind, and IMO openbmc has no unique requirements in that space that aren't covered already by that combo.  Unfortunately, I didn't write the current proposal.  Maybe I will if I have to review anymore MonitoringService code :-)

phosphor-hwmon and dbus-sensors are both relatively thin wrappers around hwmon.  I wonder if you could rewrite them as thin wrappers around lm-sensors;  I never really considered that, but it would be neat.

Reading your response, I'm trying to understand, in the context of this patch, do you think the awk approach is better, and I should be testing, adding logic to, and hardening that one, or was it just that my comment struck a nerve?  Apologies if it's the later.

Patch Set 43: Code-Review+1

Patch Set 43: Code-Review-1

(12 comments)

Sorry I've been unresponsive for a while.

I am very inexperienced reading C++ code and ignorant of constriants for boost, but did this review based on "can I read what was written and infer that the code looks like should do something reasonable".

It seems like there are some basic holes in hooking this up to the system, such as the socket unit file does not seem to link to the existing service files.  More importantly it seems the client is determining by its action to negotiate SSL the security context of the socket instead of the server forcing the context by the incoming port.  There seems to be missing interactions between the newly added config and possible breakage of the existing turn off ssl option.  And security and review relevant assertions in the commit message are stale and now false.

But there was also request for me to discuss the merits of performing the function in this server vs the approach of using my awk script, especially from a maintenance and security standpoint.

1.  The awk script is parsing a standard protocol and not using a reviewed library to perform the parsing.   The BMCweb server was started from the crow class upstream.  However, I am not aware of any ongoing review of our library or monitoring the original upstream project for ongoing enhancements.  There is still the burden of having to review two implementations.

2.  The awk script is written in a language that does not expose memory allocation details to the programmer.   A quick search of "awk cve" produced a Denial-of-Service regex exposure from 2013 and two NULL pointer exposures in the "gawk" implementation in 2016 both from parsing an invalid program.  The other hits on the first results page were hits in the advisory text describing how to use awk to identify vulnerable systems or code.

3.  Regarding resource limiting and consumption:   Having the service as a completely separate service allows one to easily limit the resources usable by the service.  While I mentioned in the design review that it would be difficult to limit the memory consumed by a single header because the read would occur into the process space before being limited, it occurred to me later it becomes much easier to set a reasonable limit the resource usage at the process level since each connection handles exactly one incoming socket.  Simply use the unit files to place limits on the socket tcp buffers and use rlimits to clamp the memory and cpu available to the service.

The -1 is because the commit message makes false assertions and because the systemd integration appears incomplete.

> 
> I am very inexperienced reading C++ code and ignorant of constriants for boost, but did this review based on "can I read what was written and infer that the code looks like should do something reasonable".

I appreciate your review.  If I can help clarify anything, please, let me know, but most of the things I'm calling are from boost, and their documentation and reference is pretty good in most cases.

> 
> It seems like there are some basic holes in hooking this up to the system, such as the socket unit file does not seem to link to the existing service files.  More importantly it seems the client is determining by its action to negotiate SSL the security context of the socket instead of the server forcing the context by the incoming port.  There seems to be missing interactions between the newly added config and possible breakage of the existing turn off ssl option.  And security and review relevant assertions in the commit message are stale and now false.

I'm not following what these "holes" are.  This patchset treats all sockets the same, which allows use cases like the one mentioned in the commit message.  Pinning a specific "http" and "https" port prevents forwarding on customized (non 443) ports.

> 
> But there was also request for me to discuss the merits of performing the function in this server vs the approach of using my awk script, especially from a maintenance and security standpoint.
> 
> 1.  The awk script is parsing a standard protocol and not using a reviewed library to perform the parsing.   The BMCweb server was started from the crow class upstream.  However, I am not aware of any ongoing review of our library or monitoring the original upstream project for ongoing enhancements.  There is still the burden of having to review two implementations.

With respect, nearly all of the crow functionality has been replaced with boost at this point, because of the exact reason you mention.  Crow was not maintained well enough for the project to be able to rely on.  About the only thing left that's basically the same is the http router, which I do monitor the upstream project for changes, and occasionally backport things that we might need.  With that said, the last commit was 2017, so it's pretty easy to monitor.
My point was mostly that at this point, we have 0 maintenance of an http parser, and only really maintain the semantics of the connection, http routing table, and upgrade handlers, which we have to do regardless of what implementation we choose.

> 
> 2.  The awk script is written in a language that does not expose memory allocation details to the programmer.   A quick search of "awk cve" produced a Denial-of-Service regex exposure from 2013 and two NULL pointer exposures in the "gawk" implementation in 2016 both from parsing an invalid program.  The other hits on the first results page were hits in the advisory text describing how to use awk to identify vulnerable systems or code.

Memory leaks/problems are not the only source of possible attack vectors, although your point is well taken.

> 
> 3.  Regarding resource limiting and consumption:   Having the service as a completely separate service allows one to easily limit the resources usable by the service.

Has that been done somewhere that I missed?

>  While I mentioned in the design review that it would be difficult to limit the memory consumed by a single header because the read would occur into the process space before being limited, it occurred to me later it becomes much easier to set a reasonable limit the resource usage at the process level since each connection handles exactly one incoming socket.  Simply use the unit files to place limits on the socket tcp buffers and use rlimits to clamp the memory and cpu available to the service.
> 
> The -1 is because the commit message makes false assertions and because the systemd integration appears incomplete.

Overall, is your position that:
1. The AWK implementation is good enough, and this is just duplicated effort/implementation that should be abandoned.
2. The commit message needs cleaned up (see comments about systemd integration, I don't think it's incomplete), and the other small things sorted, then you would support this patchset being merged, and the awk script "deprecated" (not that we have a term for that as a project).
3. This implementation and the awk script each have their own use cases, and each could/should be enabled depending on the user needs, and we should host both.


Thanks for reviewing this!

I did have a minor design thought that's going to change this code a bit.  It turns out that systemd has an API for grabbing the socket file name called sd_listen_fds_with_names.  I was intending on encoding an enum into the socket file name to try to denote what kind of channel the socket was.  Something like:

bmcweb_http.socket would host an http only interface
bmweb_https.socket would host an https only interface
bmcweb_hybrid.socket would host a hybrid (http forwards to https) socket

That would mean that administrators could have very fine grained control over EXACTLY what a given socket and port supported protocol wise, and would allow for extensions like binding unauthenticated http channels for "in the box" interfaces (like the host interface) that wouldn't require authentication.

That's going to rework this patchset somewhat.

An HSTS Host MUST NOT include the STS header field in HTTP responses

My main use case for this patch was to allow people to type in <mybmc> in the browser window, and be redirected properly. To clarify, I foresee three configuration states for the redirect feature:
1. compiled out of the image,
2. compiled into the image but disabled by the bmc admin, and
3. compiled into the image and enabled.

This appears to be existing behavior, but we should handle all HTTP/1.x version requests see https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7230#section-2.6.

Feel free to go ahead and implement support for 2.0 and 3.0, if that's what you're talking about, but those are huge changes to the protocol, and will require a large rearchitecture of bmcweb.  If you'd like to take that on, I'd be all for it.

If you're talking about 1.0, I believe this already does, hence this check for version before requiring a host header.

Was there another protocol version you were referring to?  1.0, 1.1, 2.0 and 3.0 are the only http spec variations I'm aware of.

I was referring to a client claiming some HTTP/1.x for x != 1.

As you point out this is only checking that the host header exists, and is relaxing the requrment for 1.0, so is correct from that point.  

Should we assume that 1.2 would keep the requirement in 1.1?  We would still respond with 1.1 compliance.  A minor point.

It's unlikely that there will be a 1.2, considering 2.0 and 3.0 have been standardized already, neither of which we support, and both of which require upstream of this file changes (2.0 requires an ALPN header in the SSL request, and 3.0 requires UDP sockets) so it's unlikely we'd have issues.

With that said, sure, we could adjust this check to a >= if we felt so inclined.  Probably not something for this patch.

That sounds like its what the client sends not what the server requires based on the connecting port.

> That sounds like its what the client sends not what the server requires based on the connecting port.

Part of the point of this patch is that the server doesn't "require" either.  If you ask for non-SSL, it politely (ie 307 redirect) points you to the SSL implementation.  If you ask for SSL, it just works.  "requiring" a particular port match a particular protocol would cause the example in the commit message, as well as non-standard ports to no longer forward correctly.  I've personally seen this behavior on commercial BMCs non-standard ports, and it's very annoying when you type in http://<mybmc>:4000 and the redirects fail to work.

So is the code in this commit redirecting clients to use https on port 80 ?

If not how does it decide which port to direct clients toward?

> So is the code in this commit redirecting clients to use https on port 80 ?

No.  In the port 80 case, the location header doesn't include the port, so changing the protocol is sufficient to redirect to 443.  If the client is using a non-standard port, yes, it would redirect them to use HTTPS on that non-standard port, which is I think the best we can do there (and is explicitly not functional on a lot of BMC implementations I know of).

> 
> If not how does it decide which port to direct clients toward?

It doesn't, it either uses the browsers/clients preference (which forwards to 443 correctly) or, if the port is explicit, forwards to the same port, just using the SSL protocol.
